In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) program, initiated in 2001, 
aims to achieve development through cooperation, leading to accelerated economic growth and 
shared prosperity among the 10 partner countries, with the support of six multilateral institution 
partners.1 It has evolved from a consultative and project-based institutional framework to a more 
sector-strategy  and  results-oriented  approach  in  the  four  priority  sectors  of  energy,  trade 
facilitation, trade policy, and transport. The program’s objectives are expanding trade through 
improved connectivity and openness, facilitating cross-border movements of goods and people, 
and enhancing energy cooperation. CAREC-related investments amounting to almost $17 billion 
were approved and funded by member governments and multilateral institution partners in the 
program’s first decade. Based on the findings of a stock-take report2 and an assessment of the 
opportunities and challenges facing the program, a new 10-year strategic framework, CAREC 
2020, was prepared and, subsequently, endorsed at the 10th Ministerial Conference in Baku, 
Azerbaijan, in November 2011. CAREC 2020’s strategic objectives are expanded trade and 
improved competitiveness (Appendix 1, Figure A1.1). In addition to the four priority sectors, its 
operational priorities include economic corridor development, the CAREC Institute, and selected 
second tier areas, such as climate change and communicable disease control.  
 
2.  The CAREC Overall Institutional Framework (OIF)—established in 2002 and governed 
by the Ministerial Conference (Appendix 1, Figure A1.2)—has guided the program effectively 
through a flexible and informal structure. Key achievements of the OIF include (i) reaching 
consensus on the principles of and approach to regional cooperation; (ii) formulating the vision, 
goal, and strategic priorities of the program and its sectors of cooperation; (iii) coordinating and 
monitoring the planning, preparation, and implementation of priority projects and initiatives; (iv) 
providing  a  platform  for  regular  discussions  on  CAREC-related  concerns  among  the 
participating  countries, multilateral  institution  partners,  and  other key  stakeholders;  and (v) 
building  confidence  among  countries  to  sustain  their  support  for  and  participation  in  the 
program. 
 
3.  Through the proposed technical assistance (TA),3 the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
will continue to assist the coordination of CAREC in the second decade of the program—a 
prerequisite for the effective implementation of CAREC 20204—supporting the national and 
regional mechanisms. It will build on earlier ADB ―umbrella‖ TA projects to support CAREC 2020 
implementation.5 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 2.  
 
 
                                                
1  CAREC member countries include Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, the People’s Republic of China, Kazakhstan, the 
Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. The six CAREC multilateral 
institution partners are the Asian Development Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the 
International Monetary Fund (IMF), the Islamic Development Bank, the United Nations Development Programme, 
and the World Bank.  
2  ADB. 2010. The 10-year Commemorative Study Part 1 (Stock-Take). Manila.

section of ADB’s website on 20 April 2012.

for 2012: Supporting Capacity Development Needs of CAREC 2020 and Assisting the CAREC Institute Knowledge 
Program, Phase 1, which are dedicated to the capacity development and knowledge components of CAREC 2020. 
5  Earlier ADB TA projects comprise: (i) ADB. 2007. Strengthening Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation,

II.  ISSUES 
4.  The stock-take report (footnote 2) warns that ownership of and commitment to the OIF 
has varied among member countries, with heavy reliance on assistance from the multilateral 
institution partners in programming and coordination. CAREC 2020, reflecting on the program’s 
first decade and the key lessons of the stock-take report, called for gradual refinements of the 
OIF to improve its coordination of the CAREC program. These include: 
 
(i)  a more prominent role for the countries in the execution of the OIF, enhancing 
country ownership of the program;  
(ii)  strengthened coordinating mandates of the national focal points (NFPs), ensuring 
that they have the institutional capacities to bring about focused and accelerated 
implementation of CAREC 2020; 
(iii)  a  stronger  role  for  the  senior  officials’  meetings  (SOMs)  in  resolving  issues 
associated with the implementation of CAREC 2020 through better intersectoral 
coordination—not only taking stock of progress as they have done in the past, 
but proactively addressing policy issues and undertaking annual development 
effectiveness review, using the CAREC results framework; 
(iv)  greater consistency among member countries in the involvement of their sector 
focal points in the work of the sector coordinating committees—ensuring regular 
and  consistent  country  representation  at  each  committee  meeting,  and 
appointing participants at an appropriately senior level who are authorized to 
make key decisions on CAREC policy and project issues; and 
(v)  a stronger interface with private sector institutions.  
 
5.  With a strengthened OIF to actively manage the more focused agenda of CAREC 2020 
and the OIF’s highly satisfactory coordination of the program,6 stakeholders increasingly expect 
ADB to step up its support to the OIF. The effective functioning of national and regional CAREC 
bodies under the OIF would facilitate the mainstreaming of CAREC projects and initiatives in 
national development agendas. In response to this expectation, at the 10th CAREC Ministerial 
Conference, ADB expressed its strong commitment to support the CAREC 2020 strategy by 
providing financial, technical, and knowledge resources, and to assist in the coordination of the 
program. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The proposed TA is expected to contribute to an expansion in the total international 
trade of CAREC member countries, as envisaged in CAREC 2020’s strategic objective. To 
contribute to achieving this impact, coordination of the CAREC program will be enhanced as the 
TA’s intended outcome. The vehicle of coordination has been established as the OIF. The TA 
will continue ADB’s support for the OIF national and regional mechanisms, as well as the overall 
coordination of the CAREC program.  
 
                                                
6  Positive feedback from partners on ADB’s performance has been voiced in numerous ministerial conferences and 
SOMs. For example, see para. 16 of Collective View of the Multilateral Institutions at the Ninth Ministerial 
Conference in Cebu, Philippines on 2 November 2010 (http://www.carecprogram.org/uploads/events/2010/9th-
MC/Collective-View-Multilateral-Institutions.pdf).

3 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The expected outputs of the TA are: (i) the regional and national bodies under the 
CAREC OIF increase their effectiveness; and (ii) CAREC coordination support is strengthened.  
 
8.  Effective  CAREC  regional  and  national  bodies.  Over  the  first  10  years  of  the 
program,  an  annual  calendar  for  regular  meetings  took  shape  and  is  anticipated  to  be 
maintained for the coming years. These regular meetings may be supplemented by ad hoc calls 
for extraordinary meetings as issues arise. Of the regular meetings, the most high profile is the 
annual  Ministerial  Conference,  which  serves  as  a  platform  for  discussing  and  adopting 
governing policies and strategies for the CAREC program. The SOM, which convenes at least 
twice a year with participation from member countries’ NFPs and sector focal points, lays the 
ground for the Ministerial Conference by holding in-depth discussions on sector progress, and 
proposing new initiatives under the CAREC strategy. These SOMs are informed and guided by 
findings and recommendations of the four sector coordinating committee meetings, which meet 
on average semiannually, with some variations from sector to sector.7 The TA will fund these 
meetings  and  others  under  the  OIF,  which  will  play  a  vital  role  in  efficient  and  effective 
implementation of CAREC 2020. 
 
9.  For the program in general, and the regional and national institutions in particular, to 
gain broader acceptance and support, it has been recognized that an outreach strategy is 
needed at various levels. At the national level, each member country, led by the office of the 
NFP and supported by the CAREC Unit in ADB, which serves as the program secretariat, has 
begun formulation of a national outreach strategy. They will regularly convene CAREC national 
consultation workshops, at their respective locations. These workshops will benefit from a range 
of  stakeholder  participation,  promote  greater  awareness  of  CAREC  2020,  and  nurture  a 
participatory approach in the planning and implementation of CAREC projects, all of which will 
contribute to greater country ownership of CAREC. At the regional level, ADB will help conduct 
outreach activities with a view to mobilizing further support for the program. 
 
10.  Strengthened  CAREC  coordination  support.  The  TA  will  strengthen  support  for 
CAREC  coordination  by  providing  a  team  of  core  coordinating  consultants  based  in  ADB 
Headquarters, and consultants based in the 10 member countries. The consultants will assist in, 
among  other  things,  the  following:  (i)  supporting  national  coordination  mechanisms  in  the 
member countries; (ii) planning and organizing CAREC events and meetings; (iii) planning, 
preparing, and monitoring CAREC 2020 projects; (iv) monitoring the development effectiveness 
of the CAREC program for strategic decision making; (v) liaising with other CAREC multilateral 
institution partners and stakeholders; (vi) updating the CAREC 2020 rolling medium-term priority 
projects list; (vii) helping conduct selected small studies as requested by CAREC national and 
regional bodies; and (viii) undertaking effective advocacy and outreach activities. They will also 
help  with  information-sharing  activities  with  other  development  partners  and  regional 
organizations  to maximize  opportunities for  regional  cooperation  and  to  avoid  overlap  and 
duplication of efforts. 
 
11.  The consultants, based in the participating countries, act as national advisors to the 
NFPs and regional cooperation coordinators (RCCs). The advisors assist the NFPs with in-

Committee, and the Customs Cooperation Committee (Trade Facilitation Sector). The World Bank provides

country  coordination  among  ministries  and  agencies,  to  monitor  and  promote  timely 
implementation  of  CAREC  agreements  and  events.  The  advisors  and  the  RCCs  facilitate 
coordination with the CAREC Unit staff and consultants in ADB Headquarters. Among other 
tasks, the RCCs support preparation of reports and organization of meetings and other events. 
The advisors and RCCs help ensure that national commitments made during CAREC events 
are followed up and acted upon. Since February 2012, advisors and RCCs have been helping 
keep track of progress on key CAREC activities in member countries through their monthly 
reports to ADB. These reports also cover developments related to other (non-CAREC) regional 
cooperation initiatives. 
 
12.  With support from the TA, CAREC consultants will continue to improve the presentation 
and  content  of  the  CAREC  program  website  (www.carecprogram.org).  They  will  also  help 
organize events and forums to promote private sector participation in CAREC initiatives.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF), comprising $2,300,000 equivalent from TASF-IV and $700,000 equivalent from TASF-
other sources. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The TA will be implemented over 36 months during September 2012–August 2015. ADB 
will be the executing agency, with the CWRD acting as the focal point. 
 
15.  The TA will finance approximately 10 person-months of international and 324 person-
months of national consulting services engaged annually during the implementation period. 
Consultants will be employed by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). International consultants will include experts 
in  sector  and  regional  cooperation,  and  public  relations.  National  consultants  will  include 
national advisors to the CAREC NFPs, RCCs, sector experts and coordinators, a regional 
cooperation program officer, a regional cooperation program analyst, a web developer and 
administrator, a website and publications expert, and an administrative assistant. International 
and national resource persons will also be engaged. The consultants’ outline terms of reference 
are in Appendix 4. The consultants will be recruited as individuals, and not through a firm, 
because  (i)  they  will  be  operating  in  different  countries;  (ii)  their  work  and  outputs  are 
independent of each other; and (iii) overall management of the consultants will be performed by 
the CAREC Unit within the CWRD. 
 
16.  Equipment budgeted for under the TA consists of computers and small office equipment 
that will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended 
from  time  to  time).  Disbursements  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  the  ADB's  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
17.  The outputs of the TA will be disseminated at CAREC ministerial conferences, which 
receive significant media coverage, and through the CAREC program website. Good practices 
and lessons learned will be documented in the progress reports submitted to CAREC senior 
officials and discussed during the senior officials’ meetings. All such reports will be posted 
regularly on the CAREC program website, and shared with ADB’s Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Community of Practice.

5 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
18.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $3,000,000 on a grant basis for Enhancing Coordination of the 
Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  A team of individual consultants will be engaged to support a range of activities under 
the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) program. Approximately 10 person-
months of international and 324 person-months of national consulting services will be engaged 
annually during the technical assistance (TA) implementation period. The indicative person-
month allocation and terms of reference are set out below. 
 
 
B.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Sector and Regional Cooperation Experts (8 person-months) 
2.  Consultant(s)  will  be  engaged  to  serve  as  experts  in  the  four  priority  sectors  of 
cooperation under CAREC. The consultant(s) will provide technical advice on a range of issues 
relating to regional economic cooperation and support the implementation of CAREC strategies 
and action plans and CAREC 2020. The consultant’s responsibilities will include but not be 
limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Perform  analytical  studies  of  regional  cooperation  in  relation  to  further 
strengthening  of  the  Overall  Institutional  Framework  (OIF)  and  the  strategic 
direction of the CAREC program.  
(ii)  Perform other analytical and sector studies as required.  
(iii)  Assist in the implementation of CAREC 2020 and updating the CAREC 2020 
rolling business plan.  
(iv)  Assist in the implementation of sector strategies and implementation action plans 
under the CAREC program.  
(v)  Advise the CAREC  Unit in establishing productive working relationships with 
other regional cooperation organizations working in Central Asia and neighboring 
countries, as well as with bilateral and multilateral donors interested in CAREC. 
(vi)  Advise  on,  and  assist  in,  promoting  participation  of  the  private  sector  and 
business communities in the CAREC program.  
(vii)  Assist the head of the CAREC Unit in planning, preparing for, and implementing 
conferences and meetings for the CAREC program, including the preparation of 
resource papers.  
(viii)  Provide other technical and coordinating support to the OIF, as required. 
 
2.  Public Relations Experts (2 person-months) 
3.  Public  relations  experts  will  be  engaged  to  help  in  the  production  of  promotional, 
informational, and general media materials, in addition to specific media packages for CAREC's 
high-profile meetings, projects, and activities. Consultant(s) will also support outreach activities 
and arrange for media coverage of high-profile CAREC meetings, projects, and activities, as

C.  National Consultants 
 
1.  National Advisors to the CAREC National Focal Points (10 positions; total of 
120 person-months, annually) 
4.  Consultants will be engaged (one per CAREC participating country) to serve as primary 
liaison between the national focal points (NFPs) and ADB. The consultant’s responsibilities will 
include but not be limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Provide advisory services and other assistance to the NFP in institutionalizing 
regional  cooperation  and  in  planning  and  implementing  regional  cooperation 
activities. 
(ii)  Assist in all aspects of work related to the country’s participation in the CAREC 
program. 
(iii)  Help develop and strengthen channels of communication to support the NFP’s 
coordination  activities  related  to  regional  cooperation  and  ensure  effective 
information dissemination and coordination. 
(iv)  Cooperate  closely  with  the  CAREC  Unit,  the  CAREC  regional  cooperation 
coordinator,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  country  director  and  other 
resident mission staff to ensure effective implementation of CAREC program 
strategies and activities, including activities of the CAREC Institute. 
(v)  Assist the government with preparations for CAREC meetings and conferences, 
by  organizing  in-country  consultation  meetings  with  relevant  agencies  and 
preparing supporting materials such as position papers, briefing notes, speeches 
and presentations. 
(vi)  Support  implementation  of  the  strategic  framework  CAREC  2020,  through 
CAREC sector strategies and action plans, the CAREC Institute strategy and 
action plan, and development and maintenance of the CAREC portfolio and 
pipeline of regional projects.  
(vii)  Conduct monthly updates on regional cooperation activities. 
(viii)  Assist in the preparation of studies and other research on regional cooperation 
conducted in-country under CAREC. 
 
2.  Regional Cooperation Coordinators (10 positions; total of 120 person-months, 
annually) 
5.  Consultants will be engaged (one per CAREC participating country) to serve as a focal 
point on regional economic cooperation in the CAREC participating country. The consultant’s 
responsibilities will include but not be limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Coordinate CAREC-related issues with national and sector focal points in the 
government, other government bodies involved in regional cooperation activities, 
representatives of multilateral institution partners and other development partners 
in the field, business communities, and other stakeholders. 
(ii)  Undertake  or  provide  inputs  into  CAREC-related  economic research,  studies 
(sector, strategy, or thematic), and other analytical work, including assistance in 
monitoring implementation of the strategic framework CAREC 2020, and CAREC 
program strategies and activities, including activities of the CAREC Institute. 
(iii)  Assist in the logistics and other arrangements for meetings and conferences 
under the OIF, including ad hoc working group meetings, sector coordinating

Appendix 4  13 
committee meetings, senior officials' meetings, and ministerial conferences, as 
well as in-country workshops and outreach seminars.  
(iv)  Monitor programs and initiatives of the government, regional organizations, and 
other stakeholders  on regional  economic  cooperation;  identify,  evaluate,  and 
recommend potential areas for collaboration.  
 
3.  Sector  Experts  and  Coordinators  (2  positions,  total  of  24  person-months, 
annually) 
6.  Consultants will be engaged to undertake analysis and prepare reports as required to 
meet the requests of the CAREC senior officials' meetings and ministerial conferences. The 
consultants should have extensive knowledge in various sectors of cooperation, including their 
country’s government policies and regulations. 
4.  CAREC Core Coordinating Consultants  
a.  Regional Cooperation Program Officer (12 person-months, annually) 
7.  A consultant based at ADB headquarters will be engaged to provide technical support 
for the implementation of the CAREC OIF, which guides the CAREC program, and to the 
CAREC Unit, which serves as the program’s secretariat. The consultant’s responsibilities will 
include but not be limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Prepare periodic monitoring reports on CAREC program implementation, which 
cover the status of proposed program activities and other related initiatives, and 
other outstanding operational issues.  
(ii)  Help prepare CAREC-related documents such as concept papers and project 
profiles for regional projects, briefing notes, and other background papers.  
(iii)  Provide technical and logistical assistance to the CAREC Unit.  
(iv)  Oversee logistics and related arrangements for CAREC ministerial conferences 
and senior officials’ meetings, prepare resource papers for these meetings, and 
perform follow-up activities.  
(v)  Assist in arrangements for sector coordinating committee meetings, outreach 
seminars, and other CAREC workshops and meetings. 
(vi)  Create, maintain, and upgrade a database for the analysis and measurement of 
results and outcomes of the CAREC program. 
 
b.  Regional Cooperation Program Analyst (12 person-months, annually) 
8.  A  consultant  based  at  ADB  headquarters  will  provide  statistical,  analytical,  and 
administrative  support  for  the  implementation  of  the  CAREC  program.  The  consultant’s 
responsibilities will include but not be limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Assist in updating information on the regional lending and technical assistance 
plans of CAREC multilateral institution partners. 
(ii)  Provide logistical support in organizing and conducting CAREC sector committee 
meetings,  senior  officials’  meetings,  and  ministerial  conferences,  as  well  as 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
outreach seminars and other workshops. 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
(iii)  Collect statistical data and maintain a database in support of the requirements of 
CAREC reports and publications.

14  Appendix 4 
 
 
(iv)  Maintain an orderly and up-to-date resource library (including electronic copies) 
of TA files, CAREC documents, consultants’ reports, and other research and 
background papers on regional cooperation. 
 (v)  Ensure the smooth flow of documents and communications between the CAREC 
Unit and various divisions of the Central and West Asia Department, the East 
Asia Department, and the resident missions. 
 
c.  Web Developer and Administrator (12 person-months, annually)  
9.  The consultant will primarily support the design, development, and maintenance of the 
CAREC program website, with a focus on technical issues. The consultant’s responsibilities will 
include but not be limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Assist in improving the design and navigation facility of the CAREC program 
website,  hosted  outside  ADB,  using  available  technologies  and  related  free 
programs from the internet, and in collaboration with the CAREC web team.  
(ii)  Assist in conceptualizing and executing database-related systems for the website.  
(iii)  Develop, maintain and improve the website’s management systems for content, 
documents, projects, events, and resources.  
(iv)  Assist  in  development  of  interactive  maps  for  CAREC  transport  and  energy 
corridors. 
(v)  Assist in developing, improving, and maintaining the Russian-language version of 
the content management system and mirror website in Russian, in collaboration 
with the CAREC Russian language information technology (IT) assistant. 
(vi)  Coordinate with relevant ADB departments on IT-related matters, as necessary. 
(vii)  Assist in the administration of the database and web server operating systems, 
as necessary.  
(viii)  Manage the development server hosted outside ADB. 
(ix)  Undertake other IT-related tasks necessary for updating website contents. 
 
d.  Website and Publications Expert (12 person-months, annually)  
10.  The consultant will assist the CAREC Unit with development and maintenance of the 
CAREC program website, and assist in editorial and/or proofing work for CAREC publications. 
The consultant’s responsibilities will include but not be limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Assist in the development and maintenance of the CAREC program website, 
including  the  CAREC  Institute  web  page  content  embedded  in  the  CAREC 
program site. 
(ii)  Develop content for the CAREC program website, for all new web pages, in a 
timely manner. 
(iii)  Develop  and  implement  a  schedule  to  ensure  regular  and  comprehensive 
updating of all website pages. 
(iv)  Coordinate with ADB’s Department of External Relations to develop, maintain, 
and update the CAREC program website pages of www.adb.org. 
(v)  Provide inputs, as requested, for other CAREC information materials. 
(vi)  Edit and/or proof read other CAREC publication materials, as requested. 
(vii)  Undertake other related activities assigned by the CAREC Unit, including for 
example, the preparation of presentation materials, reports, and other documents 
for use in high-level meetings and conferences.

Appendix 4  15 
 
e.  Administrative Assistant (12 person-months, annually) 
11.  An  administrative  assistant  will  be  engaged to  provide  administrative  support to  all 
aspects of the work of the CAREC Unit. 
 
D.  Other Consultants 
 
1.  International and National Resource Persons  
12.  Resource  persons  may  be  engaged  to  work  closely  with  responsible  ADB  staff  in 
preparing specific materials and making presentations at meetings and workshops.  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.
